repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - Wastewater Disposal in
            Tourism Centers

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Wastewater Disposal
            in Tourism Centers for Dominican Republic was satisfactory,
            the sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. Following are lessons
            learned from the project: The investment component of the
            project was designed to be readily managed, funded and
            supervised. The institutional component of the project would
            have benefited from a comparable, less-aggressive approach.
            The outcome of the project is totally consistent with the
            conclusions of the Quality at Entry Assessment performed in
            April 2001. In the opinion of the panel that performed the
            assessment, the LIL was adequate for piloting the ocean
            outfall technology. There should always be an institutional
            contingency plan for reform projects.

repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - Wastewater Disposal in
            Tourism Centers Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Wastewater Disposal in Tourism
            Centers Project aims at applying innovative technology for
            environmentally sound disposal of treated wastewater, in
            coastal towns, and, prepare a model to incorporate the
            private sector in the provision of water supply services in
            selected tourism areas. The components will: 1) include the
            construction of wastewater conveyance systems, treatment
            installations, and submarine out-falls in the Sosua region.
            Existing sewage will be connected to the treatment plant,
            along with the necessary construction of pumping stations;
            2) prepare, and implement the private sector participation
            process for the provision of water supply services in the
            Puerto Plata, Sosua, and Cabarete region. It includes
            procurement drafting for the management of these services in
            the pilot region, technical assistance to support the
            evaluation/selection process, and, to design contracting
            regulations; 3) monitor coastal environment, testing the
            effectiveness of the small-diameter submarine out-fall,
            through key indicator variables, and their effect on
            wastewater disposal; 4) in partnership with the Pan-American
            Health Organization, training and dissemination practices
            will form the basis for a case study on the technical
            viability of small-diameter out-falls; 5) provide technical
            and financial support to design control regulations on
            operational, and environmental aspects.

repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - Wastewater Disposal in
            Tourist Centers Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Wastewater Disposal in Tourist Centers Project, which
            designs and builds a waste collection system, improves the
            existing treatment plant, and builds a submarine discharge
            to transmit wastes from the treatment plant. The
            environmental impacts anticipated are considered minor, and
            are largely associated with the impacts of construction,
            some minor disturbance of the coastal vegetation, and
            alteration of the submarine community in the vicinity of the
            discharge pipe. Construction, operation, and maintenance of
            the wastewater treatment system represents the principal
            sources of potential negative environmental impacts
            resulting from the project. Poor construction promoting
            leakage of transmission lines, failure of the operator to
            properly dispose of solids collected from the system, and
            failure to maintain the submarine discharge in good working
            order are the principal risks from the project. The
            mitigation of the environmental impacts associated with this
            project are largely related to insuring that the design and
            construction is adequately implemented (contract clauses in
            project bidding documents will contain environmental
            requirements and contracts will be evaluated on that basis),
            personnel are adequately trained, and that the operation of
            the facility complies with project requirements over the
            life of the project.
